results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 22]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur cinematographer and filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

In this film, Wallace films the city of Shanghai in China, and its people. Crowded streets, heavy traffic (with many bicycles), houses, shops and other buildings, gardens, the city’s canals and port are features. There are scenes of people at work, and children in organised cultural activities, and a sequence of high-vantage-point views of the city dissolve into one another. The Jade Buddha Temple with its many statues is also featured.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 Wallace Clarke titles ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘Shanghai’, ‘Filmed by W.H.C’
00:01:26:99 carpet weaving
00:02:34:00 jade ‘Buddha Temple’ and its Buddha statues
00:04:57:00 various views of the city from high vantage points, in a sequence of dissolves.
00:05:56:00 young children at school or kindergarten
00:11:50:00 port and ships
00:13:41:00 shadow puppet play
00:14:04:00 young children in various music, calligraphy, arts and electronics activities in a sequence of dissolves. Some children wear the red scarf of the ‘Young Pioneers of China’ youth organisation.
00:15:45:00 title ‘The End’

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 21]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur cinematographer and filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

After his signature opening title, ‘Round About Alice’, Wallace goes to the desert landscape around Alice Springs, in the Northern Territory, including close-ups of wildflowers and distance shots of ‘Mount Conner’. We see Alice Springs streets and landmarks, and the annual (since 1970) ‘Alice Springs Lions Club Camel Cup’ race. Features the historic Alice Springs Telegraph Station (1872), once also the site of ‘The Bungalow’ school, (1932-1942) for children then identified by government as ‘part aboriginal’. Wallace then films in the dramatic landscape of the ‘McDonnell Ranges’.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 Wallace Clarke titles ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘Round About Alice’, ‘A W.H.C film’.
00:01:10:00 classic Australian style windmill spinning in wind
00:01:14:00 Mount Conner in distance
00:03:26:00 Street scenes Alice Springs
00:03:47:00 John Flynn Memorial Church, Alice Springs, exterior and interior.
00:04:31:00 extended sequence of camel racing, including scenes of watching crowd, a Scottish pipe band, and particpants in fancy dress
00:07:21:00 night sequence with illumintaed ‘Lions Cup’ sign with outline of a camel in lihghts; fireworks
00:08:02:00 Anzac Hill War Memorial (dedicated 1934) at Alice Springs, followed by aerial views of the town
00:08:32:00 Alice Springs Telegraph Station buildings and surrounds
00:09:15:00 Gravestones in the Alice Springs Telegraph Station Cemetery
00:09:58:00 John Flynn gravesite memorial
00:10:19:00 Roadsign for Simpsons Gap followed by scenes of and in McDonnell Ranges, including camping activities.

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 20]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur cinematographer and filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. This film shows a trip to Papua New Guinea in 1961. The filmmaker captures a seaside town, fishing boats, people at a market and men in traditional headdresses, as well as the Boumana (Bomana) War Cemetery in Port Moresby.

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 19]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur cinematographer and filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film showcases Papua New Guinea (PNG) in the 1960s. It begins with coastal towns and ports, sighing, canoes and boats and then travels by plane to the ‘Highlands’ on what appears to be a cargo plane. Along the way, Wallace captures the villages, the dramatic landscapes and the various peoples of PNG.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 a group of smiling children walk along a road under palm trees
00:00:25:00 thatched houses facing a lagoon
00:01:45:00 taking down the sail on a local ‘outrigger canoe’
00:02:18:00 view from a plane overhead and a TAA (Trans Australia Airlines) plane on an airfield being emptied of cargo
00:02:32:00 several totem sculptures and carved statues
00:02:57:00 a man spearing fish in the waves off a rocky perch
00:03:09:00 Coastwatchers Memorial in Madang
00:03:18:00 ‘Petrus II’ sailing boat and unloading cargo of cacao beans in large hessian sacks from a boat onto a pier
00:03:54:00 a lovely old rusty shed, jetty and boats in a palm tree setting
00:04:04:00 school girls playing sport
00:04:29:00 fixing a car in a village of thatch covered houses
00:05:04:00 canoes being paddled across the water
00:06:07:00 a larger boat followed by scenes around a portside town
00:07:34:00 a particularly picturesque roadside store, Central Merchants, and people carrying goods on shoulders and heads
00:08:34:00 ‘44 gallon drums’ being unloaded from a plane by being bounced onto a large rubber tyre
00:08:54:00 aeriel views over the jungles and mountains and misty clouds
00:09:24:00 a long winding river being filmed from the plane above
00:11:29:00 boarding a TAA plane and takeoff with the mountains in the background
00:12:04:00 a small yellow plane
00:12:08:00 a village with thatched houses
00:12:50:00 small planes
00:13:00:00 traditional dress
00:13:23:00 flying over mountains and looking at roads criss-crossing the terrain
00:19:38:00 traditional grass mat weaving
00:21:53:00 sign ‘Kainantu Mile High Gateway to the Highlands Alt. 5280’
00:22:21:00 a large river system from overhead
00:22:10:00 a signpost for ‘Mumeng’, ‘Bulolo’ and ‘Wau’
00:23:38:00 lush valleys in the Highlands
00:25:44:00 sign ‘You are now approaching Wau, Top of Drome, Elvn 3200’
00:28:58:00 house in the trees
00:29:11:00 people washing clothes in the river
00:30:10:00 a cemetery and white crucifix monuments
00:31:04:00 TAA plane

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 18]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur cinematographer and filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film, titled ‘Papua New Guinea May - June 1961; No.1’, shows landscapes, seascapes, vegetation, people, villages, boats, roads, cars and other infrastructure of Papua New Guinea. It includes aerial footage of sea, forest, and mountains, and scenes of the (former) Royal Australian Navy base HMAS Tarangau at Manus Island.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

00:20:52:00 a food market with many people
00:27:39:00 distinctive three-sailed boat

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 17]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur cinematographer and filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film shows a group of holiday makers camping on Phillip Island in Victoria. Wallace shows several good close-ups of the koalas that are a feature of the island and one of the old kilns of the chicory industry of the past that are dotted over the landscape. There are also views of the bridge that was built in 1969 between San Remo on the mainland and Newhaven to replace the old wooden one, and many views of rolling, crashing waves on rocky coastline.

Originally made on Super 8mm film, there is a gap of several seconds a few minutes in, beginning at 00:02:42:00 and ending at 00:02:58:00.

00:00:02:00 views of the sea from a high cliff top vantage point
00:00:39:00 hikers sitting on a cliff looking out over the sea
00:00:51:00 a grassy habitat hole for an animal, sand dunes, grasslands and cliffs looking out to sea
00:01:41:00 hikers gather around what might be a weather station
00:02:08:00 a large black snake moving over the grass
00:02:59:00 the bridge from San Remo to Newhaven on Phillip Island followed by fishing boats, yachts and various views of the bridge and surrounds
00:03:42:00 fishing boats and yachts, from a view under the bridge
00:03:56:00 the piers at San Remo
00:04:15:00 the rocky shallow foreshore and jettys at Newhaven
00:04:44:00 coastal grass blowing in the wind
00:05:38:00 a foreshore viewing platform, possibly at ‘The Nobbies’ on Phillip Island
00:06:40:00 a 1970s style car with surfboards on the roof racks and two young men standing by
00:07:40:00 views of rocky coastlines, crashing waves and rolling surf
00:08:59:00 people walking along a wooden walkway on the foreshore
00:10:18:00 two men ‘mutton-birding’ - seeking out Shearwater birds (previously called muttonbirds)
00:10:24:00 a Shearwater fledgling held up to the camera
00:10:51:00 a group of hikers or bird-watchers (some with binoculars) or general nature-lovers listening to a speaker who they then clap and then walking off
00:12:21:00 a close-up of a koala in a gumtree
00:12:29:00 hikers walking along a muddy track followed by a small rowing boat
00:12:57:00 a young man with a camera and another koala in a tree

00:13:25:00 a 1970s three legged barbeque
00:14:40:00 shooing flies from lunch plate

00:16:45:00 a seagull on an old ‘No Standing’ sign
00:16:50:00 pitching a tent in long grass, a woman cleans her teeth over a bucket, a view of the campsite and a woman goes off with a shovel and toilet paper in old fashioned camp style
00:19:25:00 a group of horses
00:20:03:00 a small jetty and some boats including a yacht with a lovely red sail
00:20:28:00 1970s model ‘Holden’ station wagon vehicle lowering a boat into the water and a tractor carrying a boat to the water’s edge
00:21:56:00 one of the remaining chicory kilns on the island which would seem to have been converted to a pottery kiln (Phillip Island had a chicory growing industry until the 1960s)
00:22:50:00 caged birds of different varieties
00:24:23:00 a lone grave with ironwork surround and headstone reading ‘William Phillip Grossard’ (who died in a gunshot accident, 1868)
00:25:45:00 women swimming in ‘one piece’ bathing suits and swimming caps, walking along the beach and back to the campsite

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 16]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur cinematographer and filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film contains scenes from a trip around Phillip Island in South West Gippsland, Victoria. There are many views of the beaches, rolling waves, rocks, cliffs and sand dunes. Wallace captures people strolling along the beaches and fishing from the sand with long rods, koalas and seabirds. There are some farm scenes, of children helping throw hay to cows from the back of a ‘ute’ vehicle.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:02:41:00 seabird snuggling in nest.
00:03:41:00 a koala up close and perched in a eucalypt tree.
00:05:26:00 visitors to the beach sitting for a chat
00:07:29:00 fishing from sand, framed by rocks
00:09:25:00 hay being distributed from a ‘ute’ (utility vehicle)

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 15]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker who was particularly keen on capturing the Australian landscape from the 1960s to the 1990s. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film is made up of two films. The first captures the dramatic coastline of the ‘Shipwreck Coast’ in the west of Victoria. It also features the ‘Fletcher Jones’ (clothing manufacturers) at Warrnambool including the ‘Silver Ball’ water tower designed by Ralph Jones, engineer and eldest son of owner David Fletcher Jones. Erected in 1967 as part of the Pleasant Hill factory’s extensive fire protection system, the water tower was state heritage listed, along with other aspects of the Pleasant Hill site, in August 2006.

The second film features Victorian National parks.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 title ‘Coastal Panarama’ and ‘A WHC Film’
00:00:23:00 roadsign ‘Port Campbell National Park’ followed by views from the ocean cliffs including the Twelve Apostles
00:01:52:00 an old grave with an engraved headstone for members of the Carmichael family followed by dramatic views out over the roiling sea
00:05:46:00 the Fletcher Jones headquarters building in Warrnambool, Victoria
00:05:49:00 the ‘hawkers wagon’ emblazoned with information on history of Fletcher Jones as ‘painstaking tailors’
00:05:55:00 views around the grounds of the Fletcher Jones headquarters
00:06:45:00 old boats and sailing ships in dry dock possibly at Flagstaff Hill maritime museum, Warrnambool
00:07:40:00 the Lady Bay lighthouse at Flastaff Hill in Warrnambool and views of a canon looking out to sea
00:09:17:00 a distinctive rocky outcrop on a beach
00:09:52:00 looking out over the waterways and beaches of Warrnambool from a higher vantage point followed by some caves and grassy paddocks with grazing sheep
00:10:29:00 title card ‘The End’
00:10:50:00 title cards ‘A Walkabout Film’ and ‘National Parks of the S.E.’
00:11:15:00 roadsign ‘Mount Richmond National Park’ follwed by close-ups of wildflowers
00:12:03:00 a car with gear packed on the roofrack
00:12:14:00 sign ‘Discovery Bay Coastal Park National Parks Service’
00:14:40:00 bee-keeping
00:14:49:00 walking up a steep sand dune and down again; views of the dunes and beach; pelicans on the water; views of the sea and beaches
00:15:49:00 fishing and a child runs across the frame in ‘gumboots’
00:15:55:00 sign ‘Lower Glenelg National Park’ and ‘Glenelg River’, a large river or lagoon, wildflowers and sea birds
00:17:08:00 sunset over the sea
00:18:57:00 boathouses and small boats on old jettys
00:19:07:00 sign ‘State Border South Australia’
00:19:35:00 jetty and motor boat
00:19:57:00 farmland with old buildings and a windmill
00:21:01:00 looking out from the rocky shore
00:21:30:00 old entry signs ‘Clarke Park’ followed by ‘Dingley Dell’ which is the historic home of one of Australia’s most famous poets, Adam Lindsay Gordon, and views of the cottage in which he lived

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 14]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker who was particularly keen on capturing the Australian landscape from the 1960s to the 1990s. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film shows Wallace and companions on a trip around the ‘High Country’ in northern Victoria starting with the township of Matlock - the fortunes and population of which went up and down through the gold rush in the 1800s to logging in the 1950s - and a summer visit to the alpine district of Mount Buller.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:40:00 road sign for ‘Matlock’ followed by views of the small town, old timber houses, rusty corregated iron sheds and roofs, old vehicles
00:01:08:00 stacks of logged timber
00:02:01:00 signpost to ‘Warburton, Moe, Walhalla’ and other destinations followed by the road into ‘Woods Point’
00:02:30:00 driving along country roads and by a creek, a large lake and a waterfall
00:04:30:00 hikers on a hilly trail that features electricity pylons and overhead wires that seem to be of interest
00:04:45:00 looking out over grassy hills sprinkled with wildflowers and electricity infrastructure
00:05:20:00 close-up of yellow wildflowers and yellow 1970s style headscarf tied at the nape of the neck
00:05:31:00 hikers taking photos of flowers or grasses
00:05:45:00 travellers and children descending a rocky hill walk
00:06:17:00 the ‘fire lookout tower’ on the summit of Mt Buller, constructed in the 1960s, followed by views from the summit
00:08:12:00 a glimpse of what appears to be the ‘Enzian Hotel On Chamois’ built by local Austrians looking for a European alpine experience
00:08:20:00 views out over the mountain peaks
00:09:17:00 two people sitting in the bush with a ‘billy’ can followed by more wildflowers and views out over rocky and grassy terrain
00:12:41:00 hikers walking around large boulders on the hills
00:13:01:00 picnic on a large cut off tree trunk
00:13:05:00 a yellow ‘Walkabouters Club’ t-shirt being worn by one of the hikers
00:13:27:00 wading in the creek
00:14:06:00 an ‘A-frame’ house or chalet in the bush
00:14:40:00 a motorbike parked on a foot bridge over a creek and people in the water
00:16:05:00 a lovely old building on the creek, including rusty corregated iron

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 13]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur cinematographer and filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film captures Mount Buller and surrounds, in Victoria during the summer period. There are views of the mountains, trees and wildflowers, a river and people walking and picnicking.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:45:00 cut logs on a truck.
00:03:26:00 walkers reach the Mount Buller summit.
00:07:27:00 walkers scrambling through bush and fallen trees.
00:07:51:00 several women sitting on a large log.
00:10:34:00 people walking through very tall trees show the scale of the trees growth.
00:10:55:00 a river view through the mountain landscape.
00:11:22:00 roadside picnic.
